BC-NYHAN-COLUMN-$ADV01-BOS 
LOOKING THROUGH THE REARVIEW MIRROR 

  
 (For release Saturday, Jan. 1, 2000)   (For use by New York Times News Service clients)  
 By DAVID NYHAN  
 c.2000 The Boston Globe  
 

   OK, so I was off on the euro.

   I thought the new European currency launched last January was
going to fly. Well, it flew _ not straight down, but at a pretty
steep angle. Let me just say that the euro dove at a sharper angle
than I like to ski at.

   From a high-right-after-launch of $1.17 it kissed the dollar
almost right flat on the old $1.00 buckeroo. Hey, I'm only out 17
cents per buck, right? I blame myself for that one. But I blame all
my genius friends who boast of their NASDAQ stock runups for my
other biggest miss. How was I to know the technology-drenched
market index would run up 84 percent on the year to yesterday? Do I
know a lot of smart people? Yes. Did any of them call 52 weeks ago
and say, ``Dave, do yourself a favor and go heavy on NASDAQ?''
Nope.

   I did a little better on the politics. I never bought the
``Clinton will have to resign, Clinton should resign, this
presidency is cooked'' collection of doom-and-gloom themes. Bill
looked a little shaky at times, but it would take a lot more than
the Republicans have got to cook his goose. Any guy who has to come
home after a hard day's work running the planet and stare down
Hillary over a mug of soup and a cold sandwich is one tough
son-uv-a-gun.

   In his wayward fashion, Wild Bill is the paradigm of this
incredible economic expansion. It just keeps keeping on, and so
does Will-yum Jefferson. We're approaching the eight-year mark of
the current economic expansion. And only the truly delusional still
claim that the roots of this economic flowering were watered by the
previous four years of Bush Sr.

   Since Clinton came into power with his finger-poppin'
speechifying and zig-zags to the middle, the American economy has
performed like no other economic engine in the history of
civilization. Did Clinton ever do anything right? Not according to
his enemies, who are legion, and largely much more prosperous than
they ever dreamed of being, thanks to Clinton's eerie feel for what
should be done to keep this jalopy turning over at the elevated rpm
rate we've come to expect.

   What else happened as we scroll back through the century's
rearview mirror? We've seen the rise of the Internet, as no one
lets us forget for a nanosecond. We've seen the decline of Congress
as an institution. The turnover of the Panama Canal to the
Panamanians _ that's a country we invented in order to swipe the
canal route from Columbia _ had to be ratified by the US Senate in
the Jimmy Carter era, and it passed, with enough Republican
support, because we used to have a bipartisan consensus on foreign
policy, all through the century, up to the Reagan presidency.

   The off-year elections of '78 saw the heavily financed right
wing outfits target and defeat five liberal Democratic senators,
using all sorts of wedge issues and red-baiting. The Senate became
a more hostile environment after that bit of business involving the
religious right and the anti-environmentalists of the Sagebrush
Rebellion.

   It went downhill a lot faster with Reagan's election in 1980,
and pitched straight down with the Gingrich Revolt of '94. When
Newt's Marauders took over the House, Congress became a toxic waste
dump. Dozens of veterans began parading out into retirement, rather
than face the petty irritations thrown up by the conservative
fundamentalists. Shutting down the government twice over
now-forgotten wrinkles in the perennial budget wrangles represented
the highwater mark _ or lowwater mark _ of the political tide.

   But the radioactive residue of the Newt era lingers on. The
Senate's refusal to ratify the nuclear test ban treaty, and the
House's refusal to vote symbolic support of America's fighting
forces while the Kosovo air war was underway, were two examples of
how badly ruptured is the US Congress these days.

   The conservatives are not far off when they repeat their mantra
that ``Reagan won.'' Government has been widely discredited as an
agent of positive change. Reagan didn't win on the environment _
the children, thankfully, insist that their parents stop despoiling
the air and water and earth. But he won on taxes. The Old Gipper
may not have been much in the IQ department, but he figured out
people don't like to pay taxes. Just listen to the dreary recital
of how-I'd-slice-the-old-salami to give everyone a bigger share
that passes for the economic debate of the current presidential
campaign.

   The generic formula is: ``I'll do more for the children, the
elderly, the veterans, our brave GIs and for a cleaner environment
_ but I'll lower your taxes.'' You'd have to be a moron to believe
that, but millions will swallow that codswallop. Hey, it's a free
country. Still.

   And that's what made the world we enjoy today, living longer,
eating better, enjoying benefits unimaginable when our parents were
born. Freedom did it, the GIs did it, the government didn't screw
up too much, and we've learned not to take ourselves or our
politicians too seriously. Not a bad way to launch the next
century, even if I did screw up on the euro.

     
(David Nyhan is a Globe columnist.)
